document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic revision of the Elachista bedellella (Sircom) complex (Lepidoptera: Elachistidae: Elachistinae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6. External appearance of
Elachista
species. Fig. 1:
E. bedellella (Sircom)
, ♂ (Italy); Fig. 2:
E. bedellella (Sircom)
, Ψ (Italy); Fig. 3:
E. lugdunensis Frey
, ♂ lectotype (Germany); Fig. 4:
E. lugdunensis Frey
, Ψ (Spain); Fig. 5:
E. lugdunensis Frey
, ♂ (France); Fig. 6:
E. lugdunensis Frey
, Ψ (France).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Traugott-Olsen & Schmidt Nielsen ( 1977 )
give a detailed description of this species. It is a rather small species as compared to other species treated in the present paper. It is darkest of all the species with brownish grey forewing ground colour from where the median fascia and another fascia consisting of the medially joint costal and tornal spots are clearly visible (
Figs. 1, 2
). Externally,
E. bedellella
varies a lot in size, and to some extent in the darkness of the ground colour. This variation is largely attributed to the presence of two generations per year, the first generation usually somewhat larger and paler than the second. The male genitalia of
E. bedellella
are characterised by the rather broad phallus with one rounded cornutus with very short blunt tooth (
Figs. 58
A, B). The juxta lobes are ’average’ in length and width among the species of the
E. bedellella
complex, strongly curved (
Fig. 19
). The female genitalia are characterised by the barrelshaped, expanded caudal part of ductus bursae similar to that of
E. lugdunensis
(
Fig. 60
). The female genitalia of these species differ by the shorter ductus bursae of
E. bedellella
, being as long as the corpus bursae, while that of
E. lugdunensis
is twice longer than corpus bursae (
Fig. 61
).
E. lugdunensis
has a small, rounded and spinose signum; in
E. bedellella
the signum is lacking.
Distribution. Widely distributed in Europe. Outside Europe distributed in Russia : Transbaikalia and Buryatia.

Remarks. New to San Marino . Some of the country records listed in
Kaila ( 2004 )
may prove to be attributable to one or other of the other taxa now considered valid species.
